awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Molecular mechanisms and biogeochemical consequences of decomposer species interactions during succession in ecosystems
awd_abstract_narration:
Over 100 gigatons of terrestrial plant matter are produced globally each year. Ninety percent of this biomass enters the pool of dead organic matter in soils. However, our understanding of how communities of decomposer microorganisms process this material is not yet clear enough to predict the rate of carbon and nutrient cycling through soils. This is a major gap in our knowledge of ecosystem stability, as the biochemical process of decomposition determines the balance between carbon storage on land and the amount of carbon dioxide released from the biosphere to the atmosphere. Decomposer microorganisms are a highly diverse group of organisms: hundreds of species of microbes can live on a piece of decomposing woody debris at any one time. The objective of this research is to identify the specific, biochemical ways in which these decomposer species interact during the decay of plant matter, and how these interactions shape the species composition and total activity of these important communities over time. The results of this research will provide detailed information on the biological processes that give rise to one of the largest natural fluxes of carbon dioxide to the atmosphere. The project will include training opportunities for a postdoctoral scholar, and graduate and undergraduate students.  The PIs will disseminate a K-12 curriculum about the importance of decomposer microorganisms through summer programs for children.

Microbes are the engines of ecosystem-level biogeochemical cycling, such that their frequent synergistic and antagonistic interactions likely determine rates of these processes. A widely observed pattern of microbial species interactions occurs during decay of dead organic matter (i.e. litter), where communities of decomposer fungi succeed one another over time and track changes in the abundance of litter chemicals. Across systems, the same orders, genera, and species of fungi often dominate the decomposer community present at each stage of decay, yet the mechanisms by which these individual species consistently become dominant, and how they influence the biogeochemistry of the system, are unknown. The objective of this research is to identify the molecular-level factors that regulate these processes. While classic theories of species interactions originally developed for macroorganisms may apply to decomposers, new information on microbial metabolic strategies, such as cross-feeding between species and anticipatory regulation of growth and metabolism, may also account for the structure and activity of these communities. Changes in litter and microbial chemistry during decay constitute one of the most predictable sequences of stimuli for microorganisms in nature, yet it is not known how microbes respond to these stimuli, or how these processes vary across a diversity of fungi. The proposed research will address these questions by leveraging state-of-the-art transcriptomics, metabolomics, and metabolic flux modeling with a model fungal-litter system to 1) determine the molecular stimuli that mediates interactions between competitively dominant and rare fungal species, 2) develop metabolic network models that predict the outcomes of species interactions, community dynamics, and metabolite cycling through litter, and 3) test whether molecular-level models can successfully recapitulate community and biogeochemistry dynamics previously observed in natural litter decay. The potential contribution of this work will be a complete gene-to-ecosystem-level analysis of decomposer fungal interactions, expanding and building linkages between the fields of analytical chemistry, molecular biology, microbiology, community ecology, and ecosystem ecology.

por.por_cntn:
Our research led to key discoveries of how diverse communities of fungi decompose dead plant matter and recycle the nutrients in soils. The goals of our research were to 1) determine patterns of species changes (or succession) in decomposer communities around the world, 2) develop a model system to test the mechanisms of fungal activity that lead to these patterns, 3) explore impacts of community assembly and activity on decomposition of plant matter, and 4) develop simulation models that can predict decomposer community changes and activity. Five different projects were conducted under this award, each of which were conducted by Ph.D. students under the supervision of Dr. Bhatnagar and Dr. Segr?. The projects included a world-wide analysis of fungal community changes over time during plant matter decomposition, a laboratory experiment testing how the decomposition capabilities of different fungi are related to their growth and activity in nature, a study of how the decay capabilities are encoded in the genome of fungi, and the development of several computational models that represent the process of decomposition and the interaction between fungi as they colonize and decompose plant matter.

Through these projects, we accomplished the goals of our research and learned several important features about decomposers that update our understanding of their growth and activity in nature. In our world-wide analysis of fungal community changes during plant matter decomposition, our laboratory study, and our genome study, we learned that the inherent capacity for fast growth and plant polysaccharide break down are key features of decomposer fungi that determine their ability to initially colonize plant material and activate the process of decomposition. In our modeling studies, we found that there are rates of enzyme release that maximize either growth rate or biomass of decomposers and that these rates depend on enzyme kinetic properties and environmental conditions, including the amount of plant polysaccharide available. This indicates that the high amounts of polysaccharide in fresh plant matter may be the reason that decomposer fungi with greatest ability to decompose plant polysaccharides initiate the decomposition process. Our modeling studies also showed that decomposer growth can remain constant or increase in a non-additive manner with environmental complexity. Key metabolic and ecological factors, including species similarity, degree of specialization, and metabolic interactions, are responsible this observed non-additivity. These observations suggest that increasing diversity of molecules in plant matter as decomposition proceeds could sustain decomposer populations and that the interaction between species may be a major driver of the community growth and activity later in decay.

During the funding period, each of our four students completed their dissertations and published the results of their research in scientific journals. A major resource developed as part of this project was a collection of new algorithms for simulating microbial community dynamics in spatially and molecularly complex environments. Most of these algorithms are part of the COMETS software. COMETS is based on modeling the metabolic network of individual microbial species, using information from the genomes of the microbes and the chemical composition of the environment. Other resources that we developed include a database of plant matter decomposition experiments that measured fungal communities, a database of genes coding for plant matter decomposition across all major decomposer fungi, and a machine learning algorithm that can predict how microbial species interact based on the decomposition traits of individual species. This work will be useful for advancing the science of decomposition and nutrient cycling within ecosystems, including representing microbes like fungi in models that can predict carbon and nutrient cycling through ecosystems. Our work is also relevant to a number of microbial ecology applications, including modeling of microbiome dynamics, engineering of bioproducts (e.g. biofuels) from plant biomass through synthetic communities or modified organisms, and testing of basic ecological hypotheses about the balance between cost and benefits of the production of common goods in microbial communities.
